Award.AwardTitle: The MassBay Scholarship for Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (MSTEM) Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The MassBay Scholarship for Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (MSTEM) program at MassBay Community College supports ten full-time, rising sophomore STEM scholars that as freshmen maintained a 3.25 science and cumulative GPA; exhibited strong research and/or engineering skills; demonstrated a passion for science and/or engineering and a commitment to an industry career and/or baccalaureate STEM degree; as well as financial need. MSTEM Scholars are receiving scholarships covering tuition, fees and books; Career Mentoring and Academic Bridging Workshops; opportunities to secure a summer research internship relevant to their STEM interest; and intensive and continuous mentoring that persists after their MSTEM experience.

This program includes a highly replicable, national model that increases participation by nontraditional scholars who are underrepresented in STEM academia and careers. MSTEM uses a proven project-based learning model that engages scholars in authentic research and builds upon established mentoring and retention processes that foster and sustain nontraditional undergraduate scholars into STEM careers in ways that expand the pipeline of nontraditional individuals into the American technology workforce. A major component of the MSTEM is its partnerships between industry, colleges and universities that converge to assure the success of scholars.

POR.DRECONTENT:
MassBay Community College received a five-year S-STEM award to create a "MassBay Scholarship for Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (MSTEM)" program at the College in 2012.   The MSTEM program aimed to increase the participation of nontraditional, underserved student populations in STEM careers and thus expand the talent pipeline into the American science and technology workforce.

 

The MSTEM program awarded scholarship funding to 71 eligible community college students since 2012.  32% of the scholarships were awarded to students underrepresented in STEM including African American, Hispanic/Latinx, Native American/Alaska native students.  35% of the total scholarships were awarded to women in STEM.  

 

The MSTEM students also received extensive mentoring support from faculty and peers.  The MSTEM students received extensive opportunities for undergraduate research, and/or project-based learning.  Several MSTEM recipients participated in collaborative interdisciplinary STEM research or projects under the guidance of their faculty. For example, biotechnology and engineering students collaborated to design and test robotic systems for the study of aquatic vegetation.  Similarly, computer science and biotechnology students collaborated to develop computer clusters to compute allelic frequencies.  Scholarship recipients were also mentored to apply to summer research programs at other institutions, and to participate in student competitions in their fields. Scholars received career and academic transfer guidance to pursue their careers, or a Bachelors’ degree at a 4-year institution.  

 

The MSTEM scholars also benefitted from the connections established by the program faculty and staff with national centers of education, regional industry, 4-year universities and affiliated research hospitals. For example, one of our biotechnology industry partner created and offered a new competitive experiential learning opportunity for community college students. Three MSTEM students were selected to participate in this experiential learning opportunity.  

 

 

Most MSTEM alumni have reported satisfaction with several program elements. One MSTEM alumni reported, "I have no suggestions as the M-STEM program was so valuable to me. Participation in the program has given me opportunities I never thought I would have. My appreciation knows no bounds."  The students also developed peer networks, Other student noted, "One of the biggest contributors to my success with M-STEM was the guidance from the participants from the previous year".  Nearly 81% of the MSTEM alumni who were surveyed reported that the participation in the MSTEM program increased their understanding of their academic field, and 75% reported an improvement in interest in STEM. Most MSTEM students have successfully graduated from MassBay, and have transferred to 4-year colleges and universities to pursue bachelors’ degrees in STEM, or successfully landed a STEM internship or job. Some of the 4-year transfer institutions MSTEM alumni have transferred to include, but are not limited to, Wellesley College, Boston University, Northeastern University, Mount Holyoke College, University of Massachusetts at Amherst, University of Massachusetts at Lowell, and University of Massachusetts at Boston.  Several MSTEM students have been able to find part-time or full-time positions in a STEM field.    

 

The MSTEM program has created a highly replicable model of undergraduate education that has the potential to increase the participation of underrepresented student populations in scientific research and in technology workforce.   The MSTEM program has also helped with establishing interdisciplinary collaborative partnerships among program faculty, leading to other exciting project-based learning opportunities for our students.  The program has created a virtual platform to enable our community to share resources, publications, images and achievements with the broader research community.  Further, the existence of the MSTEM program has helped increase community awareness of the diverse needs of our student population and is informing our STEM student orientation and academic advising practices.
